showScoreExcerpt:
“Call me old fashioned, but to take a play about a woman who powerfully realizes she’s not just a plaything for men, but her own human being, and end it with a cutesy gimmick is wrongheaded. It’s another silly toy in the dollhouse.”

bwwExcerpt: Usually stripping a play down to the bare essentials — simple costumes, a few chairs — renders it rawer and more authentic. Not so in the uneven revival of “A Doll’s House,” starring Oscar winner Jessica Chastain, that opened Thursday night on Broadway. Despite an absorbing performance from the “Eyes of Tammy Faye” actress, British director Jamie Lloyd’s staging is as sterile as an operating room.
